history.content:
Advice from a fellow transfer: Scenario 1 is doable but not fun. You didn't state your math/cs background before transferring, but CS 70 is a rude awakening for most people, especially since you will really need to dissect your studying habits and how you process material if you want to do well in the class. You will probably be spending around 10-15 hours per CS 70 pset, 5-10 hours for EE 16B psets, and 5-10 hours for 61B HWs. This doesn't include time spent on discussions, labs (for 61B and EE16B), projects for 61B, and hours spent on grinding practice exams. This is doable if your work ethic is really good, or have extensive math experience, but otherwise I would dissuade you from doing it.

The way that I've seen people avoid Scenario 2 is taking 61C or 70 over the summer. However that takes away a large part of the summer, which you might be planning for other commitments.

Advice from a fellow transfer: Scenario 1 is doable but not fun. You didn't state your math/cs background before transferring, but CS 70 is a rude awakening for most people, especially since you will really need to dissect your studying habits and how you process material if you want to do well in the class. You will probably be spending around 10-15 hours per CS 70 pset, 5-10 hours for EE 16B psets, and 5-10 hours for 61B HWs. This doesn't include time spent on discussions, labs (for 61B and EE16B), projects for 61B, and hours spent on grinding practice exams. This is doable if your work ethic is really good, or have extensive math experience, but otherwise I would dissuade you from doing it.

children.subject: <md>Appreciate the advice. Something I will have to think about. If I land an internship in the summer I probably wouldn't have a choice but if I don't have anything by this winter I might just do 16b or 70 over the summer</md>

Please dont dogpile classes with 70. Its a rough class no matter when you take it, and as someone stated before, taking courses over summer is an option. I am a fellow transfer too, and if you can take something over summer, i'd do it. 70 over summer is pretty rough because things are so close together, but if you can take 16b or 61b over the summer than thats an option too. 70 is a pretty big time sink as well.

history.content:
<md>I'm a transfer in my first semester and trying to decide on a course of action for spring. I've heard the CS61B, EECS16B, and CS70 track is doable but pretty rough and while I'm sure 3 techs of any combination are rough I'm thinking of the following scenarios. 
(1). Just grind out 61B, 16B, 70 this spring
(2). 61B, 70, HSS and then next fall 61C, 16B, and Upper div 

part of my worry is in conjunction with an all-remote spring semester and 16-weeks of grind in scenario 1. But in scenario 2 I can imagine the workload is the same if not greater than scenario 1 coupled with recruiting season. 

One of my arguments for 2. would also be I could take an upper-div that I enjoyed so while the workload would be more or less the same, the grind may not be as bad when you're taking a course or two that you thoroughly enjoy

Thanks in advance for taking the time to read this! (I'm taking 61A, 16A, Upper div AC course) right now along with one club and recruiting for context. </md>
history.subject: Class advice
